metadata.title: Magnetic nanoparticles for smart electrochemical immunoassays: a review on recent developments

sections.text: Keywords Immunosensor . Preconcentration . Screen printed electrodes . Bioconjugation

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Electrochemical immunoassays combine the specific recognition of antibodies towards antigens with high sensitivity and relative simplicity of amperometric, potentiometric, voltammetric and impedimetric techniques [1, 2]. Magnetic (nano)particles (MNP / MP) represent nanomaterial with unique and attractive physicochemical properties and a wide variety of applications. Thus, implementation of MNPs into electrochemical immunosensing enhances sensitivity through capture and preconcentration of the target analyte, simultaneously providing convenient and fast separation using external magnetic fields for incubation and washing steps, mostly removing sample matrix effects [3]. This is fully established application and MPs and other relevant tools are already
commercially available. However, a more attractive role of MNPs becomes direct active participation in the signal generation as either label or part of the electron transfer chain. The general advances in application of nanomaterials in immunosensing [4] as well as design and production of novel magnetic materials [5] stimulate progress in the field. This is confirmed by nearly 800 relevant papers within the evaluated period (2014–2018). In the technically focused part of this review, we have tried to identify and highlight the most interesting and smart novel approaches with high potential for a better analytical performance. The part focused on applications reports on the best assays of clinical markers, pathogen detection, food and environmental monitoring, highlighting sensitivity, time of assay, portability, innovative and economic aspects.
The core of particles considered here is mostly based on magnetite (Fe3O4, alternatively FeO·Fe2O3) and maghemite (γ-Fe2O3); regarding the size, MNPs are prioritized, though not completely excluding larger MPs bringing non-traditional ideas. MNPs possess advantages such as high specific surface area and easier communication with similarly sized biomacromolecules. MNPs are employed as separation carriers, for biological imaging and drug delivery [6]. in immunoassays for hepatitis B virus surface antigen (HBsAg) and cardiac troponin [7] initiated the way for their use as labels. When one does not want to prepare MNPs inhouse, there is a wide range of commercial suppliers. Various sizes and surface modifications are available allowing to choose the ideal particles for most requirements. As there is a growing interest in magnetic particles in research, medicine and industry, the commercial availability is improving, too. Probably the most popular are the superparamagnetic spherical polymeric particles Dynabeads™ (Invitrogen™), which promise uniformity in size and shape for reproducible results. The size range is from 1 to 4.5 μm and they provided surfaces either uncoated or activated for further coupling (amine, carboxyl, epoxy and tosyl modified) or already coated with protein A, G or anti-species antibodies for antibody capture and streptavidin-coated for coupling with biotinylated targets. Other commercial possibilities comprise MagSi beads (AMS Biotechnology) offering 0.6, 1 and 1.2 μm magnetic particles with some additional surface modifications (e.g. silica, sulfhydryl, aldehyde, hydrazide and C4-C18 alkyl chains). Ademtech offers smaller particles Adembeads (100– 500 nm) bearing carboxy and amine functionalities for chemical coupling or streptavidin, protein A/G and secondary antibodies for affinity coupling. Remarkably wide range of magnetic nanoparticles and beads are supplied from Creative Biosciences under the brand Absolute Mag™. Diverse sizes (5 nm – 10μm), shapes (spherical or nanorods), modifications (e.g. amine, carboxyl, maleimide, NHS, azide, PEG, ionic polymer, lipid, biotin, streptavidin, proteins) and even different composition including iron oxides, Mn, Fe, Co or Ni doped iron oxides, range of metal alloys, bare particles or coated with different polymers are available.
At present, the most common immunoanalytical format is enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) typically carried out in microtiter plates; when either antibody or antigen become immobilized on the electrode, the electrochemical immunosensors are obtained. Most conveniently, the signal can be followed directly and in real time. This can be realized through monitoring of electrode impedance; no labeling is required which simplifies the procedure and shortens the time of analysis. However, indirect and heterogeneous sandwich and competitive formats with suitable labels provide higher sensitivity; several incubation and washing steps complicate the procedure and prolong the assay [1]. Most (~2/3) assays work in the sandwich format where antigen is caught between primary capture antibody (Ab1) immobilized on MPs and secondary (Ab2) labeled for signal readout (Fig. 1a). Alternatively, Ab1 can be immobilized on the electrode surface and the MP-Ab2 preconcentrates analyte using magnetic separation, transports it to the sensing surface again eventually forming sandwich (Fig. 1b). Further possibilities involve competitive formats as shown in Fig. 1c, where the electrode is modified by either analyte or its derivative. Finally, direct
blocking of the electroactive electrode surface by analyte occurs. The common sandwich and competitive detection methods employ electrochemiluminescence and amperometry or voltammetry. These are used in both possible ways; depending on the concentration of analyte, the signal is either rising from zero value or decreasing from its initial maximum.
The electrochemical measuring techniques involve classic (chrono)amperometric time recording and potential scanning in linear sweap and cyclic voltammetries (LSV, CV); potentiometric variants are very rare. Two combinations with either light generation or absorption should be included, too. Electrochemiluminescence (ECL) is the conversion of electrochemical energy to emitted light at the electrode surface; the excited state of the transformed molecules is accompanied by luminescence [8]. The reaction is triggered by applying an appropriate potential on the working electrode, and the light intensity is followed by a photodetector, typically a photomultiplier. Alternatively, photoelectrochemical (PEC) transducers utilize suitable photoactive nanomaterials, mostly nanoparticles (NP) absorbing photons, i.e. quantum dots (QD) [9]. The charge separation – results from formation of the electron-hole pairs after excitation of electrons from valence to conductive bands. The anodic photocurrent is recorded when the electrons are flowing to the electrode and the electron donor D from the solution replaces the holes. Alternatively, if the electrons become transferred to the dissolved acceptor A, complementary electrons provided from the electrode neutralize the holes, resulting in a cathodic photocurrent.
The preparation of immunosensors and the involved MPbased reagents need to be precisely documented. Diverse methods are employed including cyclic voltammetry and impedimetric techniques as electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), optical absorbance measurements, Raman spectroscopy, imaging as scanning and transmission electron microscopies, SEM and TEM, respectively, and atomic force microscopy (AFM). An interesting example of such complimentary methods is confocal microscopy used for the characterization of immunocomplexes on molecular level [10]; the analytical focus was diagnosis of AIDS using whole blood. Sometimes, such characterizations seem to be the most important focus of the authors, the analytical part being partially neglected.

sections.heading: Capture and preconcentration
sections.text:
The most attractive, simplest, and rapidly developing field is magnetic preconcentration (Fig. 1a). Thus, the analyte can be easily removed from the large sample volume, separated from the sample matrix with the help of an external magnetic field and, in the following step, detected usually in the form of an immunosandwich. Magnetic NPs are now indispensable tool
for specific pre-concentration of analytes, which are present at low concentrations; the accompanying sample clean-up provides an additional benefit. MNPs have a large surface-tovolume ratio that allows efficient functionalization and can be manipulated with an external magnetic field [11]. The use of magnetic beads in several steps of an immunoassay was reported, including selective capture, homogenization of solutions, and inter-solutions analyte transfers. The more complex operations require precise actuation of MPs by controlling the magnetic field and its gradient [12] to avoid aggregations, thereby increasing the effective binding reactions; preventing aggregations of MPs ensures that the surfaces react fully with the targets. The actuated MPs-based immunoassay can be executed on stand-alone lab-on-chip devices with embedded electrochemical sensor to implement a disposable device for point-of-care (POC) testing. Controlled (e.g. down / up) aviation of MPs enhances the capturing mechanism [11]. When a uniformmagnetic field was applied in the lateral direction, the beads arranged in the direction of the field and formed chain structures. As the field was rotated, the chains were rotated, too. Since rotation can increase the chance of binding reaction, the capturing efficiency of the target antigen was also enhanced. Four electromagnets were arranged in a cross-like pattern, sinusoidal currents (500 mA) with 90o phase-shifted amplitudes were applied and provided 230% enhanced response. Effects of external magnetic field on mixing of 100 nmMPs in a microfluidic chip were modelled and experimentally verified in the optimized configuration [13]. The binding efficiency was increased by 49%, much better compared to 20% obtained by inserting barriers to the flow path.
For capture or other specific binding, one of the antibodies can be replaced by oligonucleotide-based recognition element - aptamer [14]. Thus, the popular thrombin aptamer attached to electropolymerized layer with benzoic acid groups and streptavidin-MNPs (100 nm) carried biotinylated-Ab2-TBO (toluidine blue O as redox label). Magnetic actuation helped
to speed up the assay; it required 3 min for thrombin binding, 4 min for attachment of the MNPs, 10 s of inversed magnetic field was applied to release the unbound label, and finally 25 s for the cathodic amperometric response of TBO. Evidently, the active movement of MNPs is one way towards shortening assay times and should be more often adopted.
The electropolymerized interface used the concept of redox capacitor based on the chitosan/catechol film containing Q / QH2 redox centers [15]. It helps to enhance response for the sandwich assay of model rabbit IgG using alkaline phosphatase (ALP) label. The enzymatically generated p-aminophenol (PAP) participates in discharging the capacitor, and Ru2+ takes part in the reverse charging. The response becomes enhanced (switched ON) when MPs containing ALP within the sandwich complex are magnetically attracted to the capacitor electrode, and decreased (switched OFF) after an opposite magnet is near the top of the measuring cell. The inspiration from energy conservation systems provides robust alternative to chemical recyclation systems operating in solution where minor changes of composition result in signal fluctuations.

sections.heading: Labels
sections.text:
The classic labels for electrochemical transduction in combination with MNPs are enzymes - horseradish peroxidase (HRP), ALP and glucose oxidase (GOx) generating electroactive products. The quantum dots (QD) natively participate in ECL and PEC signal readouts, though QDs are sometimes actually serving as heavy metal carriers for voltammetric detections; alternatively, Cd and Pb-clusters were used. However, novel types of labels are examined, too. For example, liposomes [16] and unusual enzymes as glucoamylase [17] or invertase [18] are being used. In the case of these two enzymes, output of t h e immuno s e n s o r s w a s c omb i n e d w i t h t h e
electrochemical readout of commercial glucometers. This is very convenient as the electronic part is readily available in the ideally compact, hand-held and user-friendly format.
An interesting label and principle for transduction of detection events utilized the ability of IrO2 nanoparticles to electrocatalytically decompose water [19]. Faradaic current of the water decomposition corresponding to the amount of NPs label present on the electrode surface was correlated with the concentration of apolipoprotein E. Here, the side reaction typically prevented in electrochemical procedures was employed for signal enhancement. Similarly, porous MPs were based on poly{2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate-co-[2-(methacryloyloxy)ethoxy]acet ic acid-co -e thylene dimethacrylate} (HEMA–MOEAA–EDMA) microspheres (3.9 μm) produced by multistep swelling polymerization and precipitation of iron oxide inside pores [20]. The sophisticated polymeric compositions should generally minimize nonspecific adsorption of proteins and other contaminants from complex sample matrices. The available carboxyl groups were used for covalent coupling of Ab1. After capture of the Alzheimer’s disease antigen and washing, MPs were further labeled with AuNP-Ab2 conjugate and finally deposited on the carbon-based screen-printed electrodes (SPE) using magnet. The hydrogen evolution reaction was used for signal generation; in 1 M HCl, a brief 1 min oxidative pretreatment (1.35 V) was followed by 100 s of reductive (−1.10 V) potential for AuNPs-catalyzed reaction and the current was recorded. The LODs were 80 and 19 pg mL−1 for ApoE and beta amyloid, respectively, as markers in cerebrospinal fluids. However, rather high background current (~35 μA) is not favourable considering the narrow (~40 μA) range of useful signal.
Fe3O4 based MPs modified with concanavalin A served for labeling of the H5N1 avian influenza virus captured on the electrode modified with Ab1 [21]. Afterwards, the electrochemical oxidation of water decreased the surrounding pH and the H+ ions attacked the MP surface releasing iron ions. A side effect was restoration of electrode response due to the removal of biocomponents during the harsh conditions. At the end, only the reduction current was measured. This is a pitty as the peroxidase-like catalytic
properties of the generated PB might have been employed for further enhancing the signal [22].
Lateral flow concept combined with probing of impedance changes of Cu conductor beneath the capture zone of the membrane was successfully demonstrated for contactless measurement; the superparamagnetic MPs bound through streptavidin were followed at fixed frequency of 110 MHz, using 500 mV excitation voltage and Cu based coil sensor beneath the strip [23]. The signal events around few milliOhms of amplitude and 0.15 deg. of phase changes were recorded and clearly distinguished from blank - a superparamagnetic ferrofluid freely passing through the capture zone. No magnetic field is required. In principal, such direct magnetic transduction seems attractive, as the MNPs participate in signal generation; however, instrumentation is rather complex and aggregation of MNPs complicates the interpretation.
A reversed approach was based on the decomposition of the surface bound MPs labels in case of the positive assay using ascorbate generated by ALP from L-ascorbic acid-2phosphate [24]. From 100 nm magnetic NPs of Fe3O4 (mass % ratio of Fe: O of 72: 28), a non-magnetic precipate (Fe: O of 56: 44) was formed by chemical decomposition. Perhaps the rather long reaction (>5 h) is not yet optimal for routine sensing procedures. Parallel assays will be highly facilitated using the 96-well screen-printed microplate format with compatible array of magnets for an easy capture of MPs by DropSens (Metrohm) [25].
In conclusion to this part, magnetic nanoparticles open new labeling routes which were not yet considered or were not possible for the classic electrochemical immunosensors.

sections.heading: Hybrid nanomaterials
sections.text:
A tighter and closer combination of magnetic and conductive or redox active properties is beneficial for higher rate of electron transfer between label and electrode. Fe3O4 MPs (100 nm) were combined with graphene oxide (GO) using glue-like poly(dopamine), which results from spontaneous oxidation of dopamine in the presence of oxygen; afterwards, GO was reduced to rGO providing ‘magnetic graphene’ (Fig. 2b) [26]. This was conjugated with the antigen (microcystin LR, MLR) and with the help of poly(dopamine) attached to an indium-tin oxide (ITO) electrode. The competitive assay for MLR employed Ab1 and subsequent binding of gold nanorods decorated with Ab2 and a seeding thiol-oligonucleotide for starting rolling cycle amplification inserting biotinylated nucleotides and subsequently streptavidin-HRP conjugates. Such amplification strategy adopted from the nucleic acid techniques helps to increase the signal by several orders of magnitude, which is difficult for the two complementary enzyme recyclations. Finally,
response with hydroquinone (HQ) and H2O2 was followed using CV (Fig. 2c). The ‘magnetic graphene’ seems to be promising, though its magnetic properties were utilized in the preparation phase only for a convenient separation of GO and rGO, not in the immunosensing procedure itself.
Alternatively, Fe3O4-rGO (200 nm MNPs) were further modified with Pd nanocubes (20 nm) and Ab1 [27]. This nanomaterial deposited on the electrode surface provided high signal for the electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2. After binding of target human IgG, Ab2 conjugated to SiO2 NPs (~400 nm) completed the sandwich and blocked the reduction current. Even more complex label was based on the MP-MWCNT-AuNP-Pb2+-Ab2 conjugate [28]. This combination of metals appears favorable for cathodic reduction. The capture Ab1 was deposited on glassy carbon electrode (GCE) using AuNPs, too. After binding of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) target and labeling, the final step was electrocatalytic reduction of H2O2; the response was increasing with higher AFP concentrations.
The interesting self-contained arrangement with metal deposition was tested [29]. MNPs (200 nm) were initially
biotinylated, next streptavidin-ALP (label) conjugate was attached and finally biotinylated Ab2 was linked (Fig. 3); in this way, bifunctional MPs specific to the avian influenza virus H7N9 were obtained. After virus capture, separation and binding to the GCE-Ab1 surface, this electrode was placed in a half galvanic cell with paminophenyl phosphate (PAPP) and linked through a salt bridge to another half cell containing gold electrode in the Ag+ solution. After cable short-connection, the galvanic reactions in both cells resulted in deposition of metallic Ag (kind of stripping), which was eventually determined using LSV in a separate cell. The LOD of 6.8 pg mL−1 was sufficient for a reliable detection of the virus in positive chicken liver and serum samples. Two compartments separating the involved redox reactions allowed to realize the detection step in a pure solution without the risk of sample matrix contamination.

sections.heading: Direct transduction
sections.text:
The direct coupling of the binding event to signal generation requires more complex transduction mechanisms; however,
the continuous control of the surface interaction provides complete information on the reaction rates and kinetics. In electrochemistry, impedimetric techniques are most suitable for such purpose. A major complication in such direct measurements is the presence of non-specifically binding interferrents; again, sample clean-up with MNPs before the measurement provides significant help.
In order to enhance bead-based EIS techniques, a microwell / electrode array was photolithographically patterned on glass chip with each well (6 × 5 μm, diameter × height) containing a pair of electrodes at the bottom (Fig. 4) [30]. The Ab1-modified MPs (2.8 μm) were magnetically attracted to the microwells, 2–3 beads might be trapped in each individual well. Impedance changes of the whole array before and after the prostate specific antigen (PSA) binding were compared. The microwell improves the sensitivity by concentrating the electric field on the surfaces of the magnetic beads and
also enhances the reliability by maintaining the uniform number of magnetic beads.

sections.heading: Clinical marker assays
sections.text:
In medicine, biomarkers indicate presence or state of disease and help to characterize the overall physiological state of the organism (http://fnih.org/what-we-do/biomarkersconsortium). Biomolecules chosen as clinically relevant markers are analyzed in large central laboratories specialized for this purpose; large and fully automated analyzers, or Bblack boxes^, are employed. The operators insert samples and load immunoreagents as disposable kits. The system is fully established, sufficient for the relevant levels of analytes, and rather conservative with respect to accepting novel
technologies. For less frequently measured biomarkers, classic ELISA kits are supplied. The comprehensive list of blood tests is compiled by the American Association for Clinical Chemistry (http://labtestsonline.org).
Electrochemical immunosensors as well as other similar immunodevices with any NPs should be considered for special situations, when newly discovered markers need to be measured which were not yet implemented within clinical analyzer procedures. The most attractive application situations include rapid analysis at critical care units or measurement directly in an ambulance or generally out of laboratory. Here, the POC portable immunosensor format suitable for non-trained users is the most appropriate and it should play a key role in the personalized medicine. As an example, Min et al. introduced very interesting stand-alone device for the detection of interleukin-3 for diagnosis of sepsis, where rapid analysis is a priority. The IBS instrument - integrated biosensor for sepsis, was tested on the set of human blood samples [31]. The method was based on chronoamperometry using HRPlabeled immunosandwich on top of the magnetic bead. LOD was 5 pg mL−1 and reaction time was below 60 min. (Figure 5). Wireless Bluetooth data transfer to smartphone for immediate data processing and evaluation represent the current trend - let’s employ the highly capable portable computer available in everyone’s pocket.
In addition to ‘pure’ immunoassays, the specific capture can combine Abs with aptamers, e.g. for detection of cystatin C [32], carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) [33] and whole MCF-7 cells [34]. Not all papers report thorough testing on real samples; although often marginal characterization on spiked samples is shown, sometimes with missing or unclear information on dilution and other pretreatments. The more detailed reports testing real samples included saliva [35], urine [36], plasma [37] and serum [38]. Few reports are dealing with
really complex samples as whole blood [31], stool [16] and cell lysates [39]. Such complex samples help to discover all weaknesses of detection systems developed and optimized on model buffer-based mixtures.
Paper-based fluidics represents novel economical format, which can be combined with MNPs. The group of Crooks described a biosensor for the detection of kidney disease marker trefoil factor 3 (TFF3) in human urine [36]; the device oSlip employs the immunosandwich with attached AgNPs label, which is quantified in the subsequent anodic stripping voltammetry. The paper-based origami fluidic device provided the possibility of one-step assays, the electrodes being sealed to the paper body comprising flow channels with different velocities of liquid flow and very low manufacturing costs below $0.5. Such trends are addressing situation existing in less developed countries with limited technical and economic resources.
Regarding the transduction, amperometric and voltammetric techniques were used very often, utilization of impedance spectroscopy was not so frequent; perhaps, the surface with mechanically bound MPs is not reproducible enough for reliable EIS recording. For the TNF-α assay, rather complex clean-up utilizing MNPs was required [40]; the immunocomplexes on MNPs were captured by a magnet and transferred into fresh solution, eluted using 2% SDS at elevated temperature (63 °C) and the released MNPs were removed. The remaining complexes were adsorbed on the microelectrode array and the impedance spectra were acquired. Other interesting report providing clinically relevant results realized detection of cyclosporine in whole blood [41].
The clinical area is promissing for implementation of assays for new analytes and when very lowmarker levels should be determined. sections.heading: Cancer marker assays
sections.text:
Malignant neoplasms (BcancerB) are the second leading cause of death after cardiovascular diseases globally, responsible for some 9 million out of the total of 57 million deaths in 2016 [75]. According to estimates by The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), the total direct expenses for health care due to cancer in the US in 2015 were $80 billion [76]. Early diagnosis substantially improves patients chances for successful treatment and full recovery. The cancer cells emerge from the body own cells, thus it is very difficult to analyze malignant transformations at an early stage. However, many genes overexpressed in the cancerous tissues offer an alternative for analytical use and therapeutic exploitation. Tumor markers play an indispensable role in cancer detection and clinical screening [77]. Any efforts to detect cancer as early as possible increase demands on the detection methods, including the field of biosensors [78]. A new situation arises at later stages when cancer becomes manifested and metastases result through spreading of cancer cells from the original tumor. The circulating tumor cells are playing a key role, and their early diagnostics opens opportunity for effective treatment.
Use of MNPs in cancer biomarker detection is becoming increasingly popular due to the ability of Ab-modified MPs to specifically capture the target markers or malignant cells, separate them from the complex sample matrix, in case of cancer cells typically containing large surplus of normal cells, and provide high preconcentration effect. It is a big contribution in the field where it is often necessary to detect very low concentrations in quite complex samples –whole blood, blood serum, biopsies, cultivation media, cell lysates, and paraffin embedded tissue sections. As cancer markers are seldom absolutely selective, detecting only one selected target is usually not sufficient for reliable diagnosis, screening or treatment monitoring. Using combination of a panel of biomarkers increases the sensitivity of the diagnostic method and lowers the risk of false positive/negative results.
The best examples of sensitive assays are highlighted in
Table 1. For enhanced separation efficiency, microfluidics combined with magnetic particles is a well working principle. Rusling’s group is working on a microfluidic system for multiplexed detection of protein targets. They reported a
modular microfluidics for simultaneous detection of proinflammatory cytokines IL-6 and IL-8 [61]. Streptavidincoupled MPs (1 μm) were conjugated with both biotinylated HRP and Ab2 and used for capture of analytes and their magnetic separation from spiked undiluted calf serum. The magneto-immunocomplex was captured in the device by the corresponding Ab1 immobilized on an 8-electrode array and evaluated by amperometry with HQ / H2O2 substrates at −0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl reference electrode, providing LOD of 5 and 7 fg mL−1 for IL-6 and IL-8, respectively, in undiluted calf serum. Analysis of one sample took 45 min and up to 8 analytes can be measured simultaneously. A similar device was used for prostate cancer biomarkers PSA and PMSA [68]. Here, paramagnetic Fe3O4/rGO/Ab2 also functioned as an artificial substitute for the HRP enzymatic label. The immunocomplex was introduced to microfluidic chamber, captured by Ab1-rGO coated on SPE (electrochemically reduced GO, modified with MNPs) and the intrinsic HRP-like activity of Fe3O4 NPs was determined with H2O2 as substrate accepting electrons from the electrode. Reagent cost of $0.85 for a single 2-protein assay and reduced demands on instrumentation should enable such sensor format for wider use.
Magnet ic NPs in combinat ion wi th sandwich immunosensor were also employed in the determination of p53-specific autoantibodies [79]. Autoantibodies raised against tumor-associated antigens have shown high promise as markers for reliable diagnosis, prognosis, and therapy of cancer. The disposable SPE biosensor was applied for the analysis of human sera from patients with high-risk of developing colorectal cancer and already diseased patients. MNPsmodified with the HaloTag fusion protein captured the target, sandwich was completed with HRP-labeled anti human Ab2 and magnetically bound to SPE. The disposable formats are preferred in the clinical area in order to prevent contamination from potentially infectious samples.
Another cheap and thus disposable microfluidic electrochemical array served for detection of estrogen receptor alpha (ERα), a breast cancer biomarker [55]. The anti ERα Ab2 on HRP/MPs captured the target and the whole complex was bound to the DNA-responsive elements on the AuNPs modified GCE. The common amperometric HQ / H2O2 substrates resulted in the LOD for ERα of 5 fg mL−1. Simultaneous determination of AFP and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) employed probes coded by different metals and stripping SWV quantified both labels on one electrode [80]. Briefly, apoferritins carrying metal labels (Cd-Apo, Pb-Apo) were immobilized on poly(lysine) together with the corresponding Ab2 (either anti-AFP or anti-CEA) via AuNPs. Dynabeads Ab1-MPs were used for magnetic separation and afterwards, anti-AFP-AuNP-Cd-Apo and anti-CEA-AuNP-Pb-Apo were added and the formed sandwich immunocomplexes were separated. Stripping square wave voltammetry (SWV) was carried out on bismuth-film modified GCE. The signal for AFP
(~Cd2+) was measured at −0.78 V, signal for CEA (~Pb2+) at −0.53 V, both LODs were 4 pg mL−1. The apo-ferritin-based containers provide high capacity for metal labels, as the native ferritin can contain ~4500 iron atoms and this surely contributes to the method sensitivity. The improved approach [43] utilized Fe3O4 NPs covered by self-polymerized dopamine dual-template (AFP, CEA) molecularly imprinted polymer to enrich both targets simultaneously. Metal-ion loaded recombinant apo-ferritin was conjugated to graphene-AuNPs composite together with appropriate antibodies and improved LODs of 0.3 and 0.35 pg mL−1 for AFP and CEA, respectively, were obtained. The several different metal labels can be easily separated by electrochemical scanning techniques thus opening way to a simple multianalyte sensing platforms.
Anodic stripping SWV was utilized in a CdSe QD-based detection of tumor-derived exosomes in blood [56]. The relevant subpopulation of exosomes was separated from the total exosomal pool using Dynabeads MPs modified with anti CD63 and CD9Ab1s. Then, biotinylated specific Ab2s (either anti HER-2 or FAM134B) linked via streptavidin to biotinylated CdSe QDs labeled specifically the part of exosomes carrying the corresponding antigens (HER-2 – breast cancer related, FAM134B – colon cancer related). Finally, CdSe QDs label was quantified, the peak current being proportional to the amount of exosomes, starting from 100 exosomes per μL of samples from patients with colorectal carcinoma.
An innovative controlled release system-based homogeneous protocol for SCCA assay employed magnetic mesoporous Fe3O4 as a nanocontainer and aminated polystyrene microspheres functioned as a molecular gate [72]. The pores of negatively charged Ab-conjugated Fe3O4 were filled with toluidine blue and capped by positively charged aminated polystyrene microspheres. When SCCAwas captured by the antibody, it replaced the polystyrene microsphere on the surface and toluidine blue was released from the pores, the empty nanocontainers were magnetically removed and toluidine blue was measured in the supernatant by SWV, LOD was 0.33 pg mL−1. Homogeneous assays in solution as well as pseudohomogeneous formats on sensing surfaces remove the separation steps, simplify the assay complexity and speed up the response; however, heterogeneous formats provide a better sensitivity.
Pingarron’s group utilized MPs functionalized with specific capture Ab1 to select and separate the analyte from the sample matrix and HRP-Ab2 for subsequent amperometric measurement. The whole immunoassay can be carried out as a one-step procedure when both the Ab1-MP and Ab2-HRP are incubated with the sample simultaneously [54]. The formed magnetic immunocomplex is separated, washed and magnetically captured to the SPE for amperometric HQ / H2O2 measurement. This simple and robust approach allowed to sensitively and specifically detect a wide range of markers including pro-inflammatory cytokine tumor necrosis factor α
[81], oncoprotein ErbB2 [54], protein p53 [82], fibroblast growth factor receptor 4 [57], interleukin 13 receptor α2 [83] and cadherin-17 [84]. By employing specific antiDNA-RNA duplex antibody, it was even possible to detect miRNAs, which are not considered a typical target for immunosensing [63]. In order to detect specific methylation in promoter region of the tumor suppressor gene, O-6methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase, MPs were functionalized with an anti-5-methylcytosine Ab1 recognizing the target site [85]. Next, a biotinylated complementary oligonucleotide probe was hybridized and finally linked with streptavidin-HRP. The use of MPs enabled the assay without any preceding amplifications or pretreatment directly in spiked human serum samples and in genomic DNA extracted from U-87 glioblastoma cells and paraffinembedded brain tumor tissues. Evidently, sometimes the simplest approach can be generally applied for numerous analytes; this will be an advantage in case of the followup development to commercial products.
The paramagnetic properties were also useful in modification steps, especially when complicated composite materials are produced by a multi-step process [86]. The sensitive detection of CEA comprised corallite-like magnetic hybrid Fe3O4/MnO2/Pt nanocomposites as a label for amperometric detection. The Ab1 was immobilized on GCE modified by amine-providing graphene sheets. Ab2 was conjugated to the nanocomposite. CEAwas first captured by the Ab1 onto the electrode surface, the Ab2-Fe3O4/MnO2/Pt nanocomposite was incubated with the sensor without any magnetic separation steps, and catalytic decomposition of H2O2 was followed amperometrically. Thanks to the catalytic properties of the nanocomposite components, multiple amplifications and promoted electron transfer through graphene sheets, the sensor detected CEA with LOD of 0.16 pg mL−1 and a broad a linear range up to 20 ng mL−1, also successfully demonstrated in human serum.
Similar sensitivity for CEA (LOD of 0.3 pg mL−1) was achieved using magnetite-silica-polystyrene (Fe3O4/SiO2/PS) nanocomposites with Ab1 for capture and magnetic separation [48]. CdTe QDs embedded in the mesoporous silica nanospheres with Ab2 were used as ECL label providing increased amount of CdTe QDs thanks to their encapsulation inside the mesoporous silica. The immunoassay was carried out in two steps (target capture by Fe3O4//SiO2//PS-Ab1 and successive incubation with ECL label-Ab2). After final magnetic separation and washing, the immunocomplex was adsorbed onto the GCE and ECL was measured in a solution of tripropylamine; the assay time was slightly longer (2.5 h).
ECL quenching by resonance energy transfer was used in immunosensor for PSA [67]. Magnetic separation again facilitated only the probe preparation. Fe3O4 MNPs coated with MnO2 nanosheets and functionalized with Ab2 were used as the quenching probe. Fe3O4/MnO2 hinders the excitation of
nitrogen-doped graphene quantum dots (NGQDs) and thus decreases the ECL intensity. NGQDs were used for signal generation and were loaded on the nanostructured Ni(OH)2 to obtain a composite with even better ECL behavior. This composite was functionalized by Ab1 and coated onto the AuNPs modified GCE. After PSA binding to Ab1, the Fe3O4/MnO2-Ab2 probe completed the sandwich immunocomplex on the electrode and ECL intensity decreased due to the resonance energy transfer to the quencher probe; LOD was 5 fg mL−1. ECL measurements are embedded in several clinical immunoanalyzers; here, combination with magnetic separation further shifts LODs to lower levels.

sections.heading: Detection of pathogens
sections.text:
These assays must often be completed out of laboratories in order to quickly initially detect and next identify and confirm potentially dangerous substances, and initiate subsequently medical treatment. Here, the potential of MPs to decrease LODs for pathogenic viruses and bacteria is really critical, as a single microbe can potentially initiate the disease. Selected examples are compiled in Table 2.
Viruses The chronoamperometric magneto-immunosensor for influenza virus based on AuNPs was developed [93]. Viruses were captured and preconcentrated using Ab1-MNPs. Next, the AuNPs modified by fetuin A (serves as a receptor for influenza virus) formed the MNP-virus-AuNP sandwich and this was magnetically captured on carbon SPE. The immunocomplex was treated by an acid solution, MNPs were removed by magnet and AuNPs were deposited onto SPE where they catalyzed the reduction of H+ into H2. The generated current signal was proportional to the virus titer. The analysis lasted 2.5 h with LOD of 18 HAU (the HAU unit corresponds to the amount of virus needed to agglutinate an equal volume of standardized avian red blood cells).
A digital electrochemical ELISA for avian influenza virus H7N9 employed a microelectrode array modified by a monolayer of AuNPs for high-throughput parallel assays [87]. Bifunctional fluorescence MNPs (bi-FMNs in Fig. 6) were modified by co-immobilization of Ab2 and ALP. Virus was captured on bi-FMNs, followed by magnetic separation and loading to the microelectrode array. Fluorescence microscopy was used to mon i t o r s epa r a t i on o f ind iv idua l immunocomplexes of bi-FMNs, each with a single virus, onto microelectrodes. Finally, ALP hydrolyzed PAPP to paminophenol, which in turn reduced Ag+ to Ag and LSV was measured to determine the virus concentration. The sweep rate 0.1 V s-1 allowed 500 microelectrodes to be read out in about 1 h, providing total analysis time of 2.5 h. By controlling the ratio of bi-FMNs to target concentration (≥5:1), statistically at most one virus particle was captured per bi-FMNs, allowing the possibility of a single virus analysis. The wider introduction of
digital assays can solve the problem of signal fluctuations and reliability of single virus detection by counting the electrochemical signals as B0^ or B1^. This digital ELISA successfully analyzed chicken serum and liver samples with LOD of 7.8 fg mL−1, without need of complicated sample pretreatment or sophisticated instrumentation.
ECL immunosensor for hepatitis B virus surface antigen (HBsAg) employed Ab1 immobilized on MNPs and Ab2 attached on the polyamidoamine (PAMAM) dendrimer with QDs [92]. ECL signal of QDs bound on the electrode surface quantified the analyte. This method combined multiple signal enhancement approaches, MNPs provided pre-concentration and helped to enhance electron transfer between the nanoprobe and the electrode and their large surface area enhanced immobilization of Ab1. The dendrimer increased loading efficiency of the QDs and allowed to enhance the sensitivity 4 folds compared to the unamplified approach. The sensor provided LOD of 0.8 fgmL−1 with analysis time of 1 h, the authors have successfully demonstrated detection of virus particles in human serum.
Another ECL approach integrated electroluminescent nanospheres based on the poly(styrene/acrylamide) copolymer doped with CdSe/ZnS QDs and MNPs with homemade magnetic gold nanoisland film electrode for sensitive Ebola virus detection. Electroluminescent nanospheres amplified ECL intensities ~85-times compared to QDs, offering a signal amplification strategy and improving sensitivity. The LOD was 5 pg mL−1 and linear range up to 30 ng·mL−1 of Ebola within 2 h without complicated sample pretreatment [94]. The Ebola outbreak in Africa demonstrated the high need of suitable POC assay tools in order to make rapid screening and initiate treatment of confirmed positive patients.
Bacteria An impedance biosensor for sensitive detection of Listeria monocytogenes used biotinylated monoclonal Ab1 immobilized on streptavidin-MNPs [100]. After separating listeria cells from sample matrix, Ab2-urease-AuNPs conjugate labelled the captured microbes by forming sandwich complexes. Urease catalyzed hydrolysis of urea into ammonia and hydrogencarbonate and this increased the ionic strength of the medium measured using interdigitated microelectrodes array. The bare sensor was reusable for over 50 times. The LOD was 300 CFU·mL−1 in both pure culture and spiked lettuce samples. A detailed TEM image nicely shows binding of both types of particles on the cell surface (Fig. 7).
Sandwich immunoassay platform was based on electrochemical labels consisting of MPs modified with methylene blue-MWCNTs and monoclonal anti-microbe Ab2. After binding to antigen, the labels were collected with magnet and then detected on Ab1-modified carbon SPEs. sections.heading: Environmental and food analysis
sections.text:
Toxins are the main virulent products of most pathogenic bacteria and fungi; it is a heterogeneous set of compounds interfering with the affected living systems, including membrane function, ion transport, neurotransmitter release, and biosynthesis. Intake of toxins from either water, food or the environment causes serious health problems with substantially variable individual symptoms. Thermal processing such as pasteurization or heating commonly do not eliminate the activity of toxins. Pesticides represent another group constituting severe pollutants constantly spread in significant amounts into the environment and appearing in fruit, vegetables and derived food products. The negative influence is also highlighted by pesticides being included as priority hazard agents within the European water policy. Pesticides and their metabolites exhibit adverse health effects; consequently, the maximum residue levels in food were defined to prevent both acute toxicity and long-term accumulation risks [110]. In the EU, pesticides in drinking water are regulated by the Drinking Water Directive, which defines the maximum allowable concentration of 0.1 μg L−1 per individual pesticide or 0.5 μg L−1 for the total pesticide concentration. As this class of analytes comprises a high number of small molecules, the corresponding immunosensors often need to rely on competitive assay formats (Fig. 1c). Representative examples from these fields are summarized in Table 3.
The integrated amperometric lab-on-a-chip platform for sensing of atrazine was based on boron-doped diamond electrode (BDDE) modified with PtNPs as a highly conductive catalytic transducer [116]. The free atrazine and atrazine– HRP tracer competed for binding to the anti-atrazine Ab1 immobilized onto MPs, the catalytic activity of PtNPs was then exploited to induce direct electron transfer from HRP to the modified electrode. The chronoamperometric readout
provided LOD of 3.5 pM with short analysis time of 20 min and possibility of fully automated detection. Furthermore, the second BDDE was used for atrazine degradation via anodic oxidation in the same platform. BDDE is advantageous because it features corrosion stability, a wider potential window, and higher O2 overvoltage.
Competitive immunosensor for microcystin-LR detection was based on core–shell hierarchical nanostructures and CV readout (Fig. 10) [123]. Fe3O4-polydopamine-Au nanostructures were synthesized and conjugated with Ab2 and HRP to serve as a label. ITO electrode was modified by polydopamine, three-dimensional carbon nanotube/cobalt silicate nanocomposites and microcystin-LR to allow the competitive immunoreaction with Ab1. Finally, the surface was conjugated with the label and CV was measured with HQ / H2O2 as substrates. The assay provided LOD of 4 ng L−1 with analysis time of 2 h.
Label-free PEC immunosensor for aflatoxin B1 used CdS QDs assembled on mesoporous Fe3O4 MNPs as the photoactive material [112]. Ab1 was immobilized on the
nanocomposite and H2O2 served as a sacrificial electron donor for scavenging the photo-generated holes in the valence band of QDs. The aflatoxin was measured through decreased photocurrent resulting from the increased steric hindrances due to the immunocomplex formation; LOD was 5 pg mL−1 with analysis time of 1 h.
Other competitive PEC immunosensor for aflatoxin B1 was based on etching of MnO2 nanosheets for dissociation of carbon dots [111]. The competition between AFB1 and AFB1BSA-GOx for binding on Ab1-modified MPs was followed by magnetic separation. Next, GOx oxidized glucose for generation of H2O2, which reduced and simultaneously etched MnO2 nanosheets on fluorine doped tin oxide (FTO) electrode into Mn2+ ions, resulting in the dissociation of carbon dots from the electrode surface. This approach transformed the conventional signal-off competitive format to the signal-on mode, which allowed to enhance the sensitivity for small molecule detection. The changes were then measurable as the photocurrent decrease, but also visually as a color change.

PEC immunosensor employed multiple amplification approaches for microcystin-LR detection (Fig. 11) [122]. CdSmodified TiO2 nanorod array was formed on FTO electrode and modified by microcystin-LR to allow competition with free analyte and Ab1. Fe3O4-poly(dopamine) conjugate was then used as the label carrier with immobilized Ab2 and HRP. Due to the synergistic catalytic activity of Fe3O4 MNPs and HRP towards oxidation of 4-chloronaphthol, precipitate was formed on the electrode surface. This restrained the electron transfer at the solid-liquid interface, hindered light irradiation onto the CdS and obstructed diffusion of ascorbic acid, thus amplifying the change (decrease) of photocurrent. Furthermore, the electrode surface allowed to weaken the self-oxidation by photogenerated holes of CdS QDs, limited recombination of electron-hole pairs, and broaden optical absorption of TiO2 array. The sensor provided LOD of 1 ng L −1 with analysis time of 2 h, the analysis of lake water was successfully demonstrated.
Successive reports on detection of peanut allergenic proteins using amperometry coupled with magnetic separation were based on formation of sandwich with Ab1-MPs as a support and biotinylated Ab2 and streptavidin-HRP (or antirabbit F(ab′)2-HRP) as a label. The immunocomplexes were magnetically captured on the surface of carbon SPE and amperometric readout was carried out with HQ / H2O2 substrates.
The authors reported detection of Ara h1 with LOD of 6.3 ng mL−1 [113] and Ara h2 with LOD of 26 pg mL−1 [115]. The same sensing principle was later employed also for simultaneous detection of both analytes (LOD of 18.0 ng mL−1 for Ara h1 and 0.07 ng mL−1 for Ara h2) within 2 h using dual-channel carbon SPEs [114]. The authors have demonstrated analysis of real samples of food products and wheat flour. The same research group has recently utilized analogous sandwich principle also for the detection of egg white allergen ovomucoid in unprocessed (eggs and wheat flour) and baked (bread) food samples [125] achieving LOD of 0.1 ng mL−1, working range up to 25 ng mL−1 and analysis time of 30 min.
Sandwich approach was also employed in the integrated sensor for detection of multiple allergens (Fig. 12) [129]. The integrated exogenous antigen testing (iEAT) system consisted of a disposable extraction device coupled with an electronic keychain reader for rapid sensing and communication, the detection was demonstrated in single-channel and multi-channel (8 analytes) modes. The device costs around $40 and one assay is <$4; this can be further decreased by scaling-up and by using lyophilized kits. Antigen extraction and detection with iEAT required less than 10 min, the sensor provided LOD values of 0.075 mg kg−1 for gliadin, 0.007 mg kg−1 for Ara h1, 0.089 mg kg−1 for Cor a1, 0.170 mg kg−1 for casein and 0.003 mg kg−1 for ovalbumin. The system is aimed on individual users, who can test the presence of allergens in food products before the
consumption, but also on clinicians, food industry and regulators to enhance the food safety. The importance of the achieved rapid analysis time seems obvious.
Competitive amperometric immunosensor for detection of the marine algal toxin azaspiracid used MPs as a support [118]. Ab1 was bound in an oriented way to the surface of protein G coated MPs, followed by competition between azaspiracid and azaspiracid-HRP tracer. Amperometric and colorimetric readouts were performed both with 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) / H2O2 as substrates. The assay provided short analysis time of 15 min with LOD of 63 μg AZA-1 equivalents per 1 kg. The subsequent combination of the assay with 8- electrode array allowed to analyze multiple samples in parallel.
Naturally-contaminated mussel samples were analyzed and the results were compared to LC-MS/MS analysis.
Competitive immunosensor for paraquat pesticide residues in potato samples was developed [126]. The assay was based on competition between free paraquat and paraquat-BSA immobilized on MPs for binding to Ab1-modified CdS NPs. Afterwards, the NPs were dissolved byHNO3 and the released Cd2+ was quantified by anodic stripping voltammetry. The assay reached LOD of 1.4 μg kg−1 (corresponding to 5 ng L−1) in potato samples with analysis time of 50 min.
Sandwich ECL immunosensor for detection of tetrodotoxin used Fe3O4/Au MPs modif ied with branched poly(ethylenimine) functionalized graphene and Ab1, this
ensamble was adsorbed on GCE surface [128]. After capture of tetrodotoxin, the subsequently bound luminol-AuNP-Ab2 conjugate served for ECL measurement. The sensor provided LOD of 10 pg mL−1 with analysis time of 2 h, successful detection in spiked mussel samples demonstrated the capabilities for real sample analysis.
In the environmental assays, the main role of MNPs is preconcentration fromwater; on the other hand, complex food samples require clean-up and removal of complex sample matrix prior to the immunosensing steps.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
This review summarizes advances, challenges, and trends in the rapidly growing field of electrochemical immunosensing supported and enhanced by magnetic nanoparticles. This interdisciplinary effort combines the
unique magnetic behavior with additional catalytic, electrochemical and mechanical propert ies with the established recognition function of antibodies. Attention was paid not only to applications of MNPs in individual immuno methods but also the sensor architecture and transduction strategies that are perspective for further development. MNP embedded in immunosensors provide very interesting opportunities for higher sensitivity and better reproducibility of assays. Furthermore, combination with microfluidics modules, microsystems or miniaturized sensors with embedded signal treatment results in attractive analytical approaches for the fast, low-cost and economic detection of trace biomarkers, drugs, toxins, pathogens and environmental pollutants.
The complexity of the sensing structures and procedures should not constitute a complication, as the manufacturing technologies for the robust deposition of thin layers and immobilization of biocomponents are available. The reliability in

real situations might pose some difficulties, especially considering that the published results on evaluation of newly proposed bioanalytical technologies are almost typically presented as being flawless. Critical tests supervised by independent evaluators need to be completed prior to considering the final production and commercialization steps.What looks ideal in a scientific paper or on a web can be significantly less optimal in reality. For end users, the principles of the sensing devices are secondary, but performance, fast results, and economical use are the priorities.
Researchers involved in the field currently focus on generating the best possible performance limits as the lowest detection threshold, ideally at the level of a few molecules; magnetic nanoparticles are here really helpful and shifting the limits down. However, time of the whole analytical proces is rarely seen in abstracts or those detailed comparison tables; this is surely a parameter to be more seriously considered. The high sensitivity and low measured concentrations are indeed nice, but should always be correlated to the existing needs and concentrations present in real samples. In specific cases even not so sensitive methods can be valuable for situations when analytes are present in sufficient amount and other parameters such as robustnes, simplicity and production cost become leading factors. The perspective future can be also supported by a better knowledge of involved transport reactions, magnetic parameters, kinetics of interactions, electrochemical transduction and last but not least interactions between antibodies and magnetic nanoparticles.

metadata.abstractText: This review (with 129 refs) summarizes the progress in electrochemical immunoassays combined with magnetic particles that was made in the past 5 years. The specifity of antibodies linked to electrochemical transduction (by amperometry, voltammetry, impedimetry or electrochemiluminescence) gains further attractive features by introducing magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs). This enables fairly easy preconcentration of analytes, minimizes matrix effects, and introduces an appropriate label. Following an introduction into the fundamentals of electrochemical immunoassays and on nanomaterials for respective uses, a large chapter addresses method for magnetic capture and preconcentration of analytes. A next chapter discusses commonly used labels such as dots, enzymes, metal andmetal oxide nanoparticles and combined clusters. The large field of hybrid nanomaterials for use in such immunoassays is discussed next, with a focus on MNPs composites with various kinds of graphene variants, polydopamine, noble metal nanoparticles or nanotubes. Typical applications address clinical markers (mainly blood and urine parameters), diagnosis of cancer (markers and cells), detection of pathogens (with subsections on viruses and bacteria), and environmental and food contaminants as toxic agents and pesticides. A concluding section summarizes the present status, current challenges, and highlights future trends.
